fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Swapping Fuel Gas Vessel to Air

·        Observe windsock and wind direction prior to starting operation. Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, four gas monitor, FRC, hand protection and hearing protection.

·        Shut the natural gas inlet. Close the natural gas outlet coming out of the fuel scrubber.

·        Remove lock from the instrument air 1 inch inlet ball valve, which should be in the closed position. Move the same lock to Natural Gas inlet ball valve that was closed in step 2 and lock out.

·        Bleed line down to atmosphere from fuel scrubber outlet to separator controllers. (Hazard: Condensate and gas vapors pose an explosion hazard.)

·        Slowly open instrument air from inlet. Purge remaining gas with instrument air. (Hazard: Opening too fast could over pressure the system. Stand to the side when releasing or purging gas.

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Well Blowdown:

·        Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check for wind indicator and condition prior to commencing any blowdown operations.

·        Close the wing valve, choke, and the flowline valve. Place the appropriate locking device and place a Do Not Operate tag on the flowline valve. Hazards: pinch points and/or over exertion. 

·        Bypass HI/LO Safety System and override Safety Valve (SDV) by shutting needle valve located under stick pilot. Place a Do Not Operate tag. Hazard: Pinch point

·        Bleed off Service Valve on Hairpin. Hazards: H2S, Hazardous or flammable atmosphere, trapped pressure and fluids

·        Move in the towable open top tank and stage it down wind of the wellhead. Make the connection from the open top tank gas buster to the service valve on the hair pin. Ground tank to hair pin or wellhead. Note ground wire needs to be upstream of any isolation kit that may be on the flowline.

·        Install a sign at the entrance to the pad. No entry into Hot Zone during well venting without authorization.

·        Ensure that personnel, trucks, equipment, and any ignition source are clear and upwind of blowdown operations. Remember to position vehicles so that forward motion is first.

·        Open the Service Valve. Hazard: Pinch points

·        Open well to tank and regulate flow to desired rate through choke. Start the choke at zero before opening any other wellhead valves. Be cautious to always stay up wind during blow down operations.

·        When blowdown operations are complete, close the Service Valve and then remove the appropriate locking device and DO NOT OPERATE tag and open the Flowline valve, if well is being returned to production. Hazards: H2S, LEL, trapped pressure and fluids

·        Place HI/LO System back in service and remove override from SDV. Remove DO NOT OPERATE tag.

·        Return well to production equipment as it resumes normal flow.

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
POD Start-Up

·        Ensure that you have all your required PPE including work gloves, safety glasses, FRC, safety shoes, hard hat, personal 4 Gas monitor, and hearing protection. Observe windsock and wind direction prior to starting operation.

·        Before starting any equipment, it is important to walk through all the piping and ensure all the valves are in the correct position, and all safety systems are in place (PSV’s, Shutdown alarms, etc.).

·        Reset tank meter and ensure the meter has cleared.

·        Check fuel scrubber vessel: See Fuel Gas SOPs below.

·        Once fuel gas has been checked then you can bring on the compressor: See Compressor SOPs.

·        Walk down pod and verify all safety systems are in service.

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Start-Up of Edwards and Eagle Ford Well

·        Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, safety shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC.

·        Check all tree valves, casing valves, flowline valves, adjustable choke, and all other valves from wellhead are in the closed position. (Hazards: pressure, leaks, and leaking valves)

·        Walk through system and verify all equipment, and personnel are clear for safe operation.

·        Fully open wing valve and pressure up to adjustable choke. Open adjustable choke to desired rate. (Hazards: pinch points, pressure)

·        Ensure the Hi/LO relay is in service and not bypassed.

·        Check entire system for leaks. Check levels on separator. (Hazards: pressure, leaks, and leaking valves)

·        Open the well to the recommended flow rate.

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Hot Water Treatment Casing:

•       Complete a JSA and hold a Tailgate Meeting. Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check for wind indicator and condition prior to commencing any blowdown operations.

•       Spot hot oil truck and transport up wind of well and/or equipment. Hazards: Flash fire, flash back from burner, ignition source, whipping hose, trapped pressure and exceeding equipment pressure rating.

•       LOTO 2” 600 series ball valve that is up stream of check where line comes up from the ground.

•       Hook up Hot Oil Truck’s high-pressure hose to 2” ball valve located on Gas lift line and/or casing valve.

•       Pressure test to 1500 psi and then equalize to casing pressure.

•       Start pumping ¼ BPM and allow truck to reach desired temp (do not exceed 220 degrees).

•       Bring truck up to desired rate and pump designated bbl. count

•       Allow truck to cool down on the last 5 bbls so the equipment can be removed safely

•       Shut of pump and close and lock service valve (open trucks bypass valve if needed)

•       Remove trucks high pressure hose and return bull plug to 2” valve and/or casing valve.

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Communication Issue Troubleshoot

If multiple personnel are involved hold a tailgate meeting and discuss the job scope. Ensure you have all the required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, hearing protection, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check wind direction and weather conditions prior to starting the task.

Hazards:

·        Working from elevated surfaces

·        Flammable or hazardous atmosphere

·        Arcing or sparking

·        Housekeeping

·        Bypassing a safety device

·        Freewave Ethernet

o  Confirm power source

o  If locally connected to radio and cannot enter radio through Freewave Toolsuite, with correct prot-4 settings, or cannot ping know IP address of radio – replace radio

o  If can enter radio and confirm all correct settings – check local hardware~ i.e., antenna integrity, co-axial cable condition, polyphaser, and radio pigtail

o  Confirm connection lights on radio – will have one red and one green

o  Confirm link light on Totalflow board

o  Confirm Network IP settings in Totalflow

o  If continuing comms issue at the same site and device – check network for duplicate IP addresses

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Measurement

 If multiple personnel are involved hold a tailgate meeting and discuss the job scope. Ensure you have all the required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, hearing protection, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check wind direction and weather conditions prior to starting the task.

Hazards:

·        Gas and fluid leak

·        Fire or explosion

·        Valves not in the correct position

·        Blocked flow

·        High pressure

·        Loud Noise

·        Flammable or hazardous atmosphere

·        Trapped pressure

·        H2S exposure

·        In the line of fire

·        Housekeeping

·        Arcing or sparking

·        Bypassing a safety device


·        Gas Meter

o  Blow down meter to atmosphere – reference SP~14.7, DP~0, and Temp~ with fluke meter

o  If issue found calibrate meter and perform checks after calibration

o  If all valves appear good – check plate size in meter run can confirm size in meter

o  Is the orifice plate bevel downstream

·        Coriolis

o  Isolate downstream valve from meter and verify zero

o  If zero fails – can calibrate zero, proof meter

o  No Density/Comms – confirm comms from Transmitter to core, if good- power cycle transmitter, if still no comms-replace RS-485 comm card in the Totalflow

o  Also, confirm pulse inputs all the way to the AGA-7 app

·        Water Turbine

o  Manually dump water line and check for pulses to AGA-7 app

o  Confirm settings and K-Factor in MC-III meter

o  Trigger Mag pick to simulate flowrate

o  If no flow by simulation – problem is between MC-III and Totalflow

o  If simulation works – pull turbine body and inspect

fields.name: Gaslift_Type
fields.fieldText: Gaslift Type

fields.fieldText: Hot Water Treatment Type

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Defrosting Hydrates

Purpose of the SOP: The objective of this SOP is to provide operational standards to guide personnel how to remove an ice plug from Choke, Separator, Hairpin and Meter Tube to prevent harm and damage to equipment.

PPE required: Hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed boots, personal four gas monitor, hearing protection, hand protection, and FRC’s.

 

Defrosting Ice Block from Choke:

·        Observe windsock and wind direction prior to commencing operation. Gas and fluid leaks are a fire and explosion hazard. Always be aware of wind direction and move up wind in case of gas or fluid release. Be sure to have a fire extinguisher that is full and in working condition at all times to put out an incipient fire.     

·        Ensure that all PPE is in good working condition, keep non-intrinsically safe electronic devices away from work area. Shut in wing valve first, then upper master valve. Place the appropriate locking devices and DO NOT OPERATE tags. (Hazards: leaking valves, hazardous or flammable atmosphere, and pressure)

·        Check the pressure gauge above the crown valve and slowly bleed the pressure off. Place the appropriate locking device and DO NOT OPERATE tag on the flow line valve in the closed position. (Hazards: pressure, leaks, pinch points, and leaking valves)

·        Ensure the SDV is wheeled in the correct position to make certain there is no trapped pressure. Bleed the pressure off through the ½” needle valve and check the pressure gauge on the hair pin into grounded metal containment bucket to ensure no pressure. (Hazards: trapped pressure)

·        Close the ½’ needle valve and tighten the ½’. Remove the locking device and DO NOT OPERATE tag from the 3” flow line valve and slowly equalize pressure to the hair pin. (Hazards: pressure)

·        Put the stick pilot back in service and wheel your SDV back out. Ensure that the positive choke is not leaking pressure. If choke is adjustable, have it set on 0. Remove the locking devices and DO NOT OPERATE tags from upper master and wing valves. Open the Upper master valve to be aware of tubing pressure. (Hazards: pressure)

 

Removing Ice Plug in Separator Gas Production Sales Line

·        Ensure that you have all your required PPE including Hard hat, safety glasses, safety shoes, four gas monitor, FRC, hand protection and hearing protection.

·        Shut in the well using manual wing valve and check to see that SDV is also closed. The well is likely to be down due to high line pressure due to the icy condition of the gas sales line. (If SDV has been activated shut in the wing valve. Lock and tag out the well. If more than one person is working on this project a lock box will be necessary. Follow all LOTO procedures. Place a chain and lock on a closed wing valve to a closed upper master valve.)                         

·        Verify TotalFlow is not showing a flow rate. (If a flowrate is detected cease operation flag the well and notify your supervisor.)   

·        Verify pressure in vessel is at a safe pressure.  

·        Visually inspect gas sales line. (If valve is closed fully or partially check pressures and open valve.)   

·        Verify the methanol supply line valve is the open position. Inspect the line for frays, nicks, cuts, or crimps. Check the methanol tank and pump to ensure it has fluid and is pumping. (If valve is closed, open it. If methanol tank is empty or pump is not pumping for any reason, contact your chemical distributor.)

·        Close ball valve downstream of the (BPV) back pressure valve on gas sales line. (Hazards: pressure)

·        Close ball valve upstream of the Total Flow Meter on the gas sales line.    

·        Close valves below the Total Flow Meter.     

·        Relieve pressure on the Total Flow meter. Close the knob once the pressure is properly relieved. Use grounded metal bucket to catch any fluid that may be present. (Hazards: fumes, and pressure)     

·        Open valve on gas sales line. Drain until gas has dissipated from the sales line. After gas has dissipated close the valve. (Hazards: fumes, and pressure)    

·        Wait 30 minutes for methanol to dissolve the icy condition present in the sales line.   

·        Open the valve upstream of the Total Flow Meter slowly until pressures are equal.  

·        Close the valve. Drain the pressure as indicated in step 12. Repeat every 30 minutes until icy conditions dissipate. (Hazards: fumes, and pressure)   

·        Open the valves below the Total Flow Meter. Slowly open the ball valve upstream of the Total Flow Meter. Slowly open the valve downstream of the back pressure valve on the gas sales line.    

·        Bring well back into production. Monitor the line pressure. Monitor vessel pressure for signs for erratic pressure conditions.

 

Defrost Ice Plug on the Hairpin Flowline

·        Observe windsock and wind direction prior to starting operation.

Always be aware of the wind direction and be prepared to move up wind in case of any gas or fluid leak.

·        Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, four gas monitor, FRC, hand protection, and hearing protection.

·        Read pressure on flowline and verify high pressure.

·        Close the wing valve. Shut the flow line valve. (Hazards: leaking valves, fumes, pinch points and pressure)

·        Open the 2” valve and needle valve to check pressure with gauge. Verify pressure is zeroed out, remove the gauge, and blow down. (Let the hydrates thaw out). (Hazards: trapped pressure)

·        Shut the 2” valve and needle valve. If pressure readings still exist, then inject methanol to unplug ice plug. (Hazards: trapped pressure)    

·        Hook up methanol upstream of the choke. Open the choke all the way. Pump methanol until the ice plug is thawed out.

·        Open the flow line valve. Open the wing valve. (Hazards: leaking valves, fumes, and pressure)

 

Defrosting Ice Plug in Meter Tubing

  • Have available and use all required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, safety footwear, four gas monitor, FRC, and proper hand protection.    
  • Perform JSA.      
  • Place bucket under the valves on the meter. Ground the bucket to the skid. Close both of the ½ inch stainless steel ball valves on the sales line that connect from the tubing to the TotalFlow meter. Place the appropriate locking device and DO NOT OPERATE tag on both valves.    
  • Remove the plug and open the needle valve allowing the ice to blow out. Close the needle valve and repeat as needed on the next needle valve for accurate flow rate and pressure readings. Ensure to close all 3 valves and replace plugs when finished.      
  • Remove the locking devices and DO NOT OPERATE tags from the ½ inch stainless steel ball valves on the sales line, and then open the ½ inch ball valves on the sales line.     
  • Open the needle valves to ensure the tubing is free of debris and ice block. Close the valves immediately and replace the plugs. Check the meter for proper pressure readings and flow rate.

fields.name: Procedure
fields.fieldText:
Instrumentation

If multiple personnel are involved hold a tailgate meeting and discuss the job scope. Ensure you have all the required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, hearing protection, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check wind direction and weather conditions prior to starting the task.


Hazards:

·      Gas and fluid leak

·      Fire or explosion

·      Valves not in the correct position

·      Blocked flow

·      High pressure

·      Loud Noise

·      Flammable atmosphere

·      Trapped pressure

·      H2S exposure

·      In the line of fire

·      Housekeeping

·      Arcing or sparking

·      Bypassing a safety device


·      Positioners

o  If device is blank or not responding – check for power supply

o  If no power trace to power source – i.e., fuse, module, wiring

o  If device is not reacting – check for instrument supply air

o  If no air, trace source until instrument supply air pressure is found -i.e. possible closed valve, bad regulator, blocked line

o  If power and air are good change device


·      Pressure Transmitters

o  Device has not signal – check power

o  Device is on, but no signal – check voltage on signal wires

o  No signal and good input voltage – change device

o  Have signal but sporadic – refer to trends and graphs for further troubleshooting, can calibrate, can delete old cal and re-cal, noise in signal can also be from corroded wires or faulty ground

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Line Locating

If multiple personnel are involved hold a tailgate meeting and discuss the job scope. Ensure you have all the required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, hearing protection, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check wind direction and weather conditions prior to starting the task.

Hazards:

·        Gas and fluid leak

·        Fire or explosion

·        High pressure

·        Loud Noise

·        Flammable or hazardous atmosphere

·        Animals

·        H2S exposure

·        Arcing or sparking


o  Determine what type of ticket you are responding to (Normal, Update, Emergency)

o  Review the work information section of the ticket for detailed information

o  Review the ticket for location (address or coordinates)

o  Call the contact for details regarding the work

o  Mark the assets in the affected area

o  Contact the representative on the ticket and let them know the line has been marked.

fields.name: Measurement_Type
fields.fieldText: Measurement Type

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Meter Calibration

If multiple personnel are involved hold a tailgate meeting and discuss the job scope. Ensure you have all the required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, hearing protection, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check wind direction and weather conditions prior to starting the task.

Hazards:

·        Gas and fluid leak

·        Fire or explosion

·        Valves not in the correct position

·        Blocked flow

·        High pressure

·        Loud Noise

·        Flammable or hazardous atmosphere

·        Trapped pressure

·        H2S exposure

·        In the line of fire

·        Housekeeping

·        Arcing or sparking

·        Bypassing a safety device

·        Gas Meter

o  Temperature

§ Setup up Fluke Temp probe into test port on meter run

§ Allow to condition for several minutes before comparing readings

§ Totalflow Temp should be within 2 degrees of Fluke

§ If not – can enter a bias +/- up to 5, if over 5 degrees replace RTD

o  Static Pressure

§ Isolate and blow meter to atmosphere

§ Check 3 ranges with crystal gauge – atmosphere, over 800 psi (for high range), and a midpoint between upper and lower

§ If any point check is off greater that 2 psi, calibrate SP and re-check ranges after calibration

o  Differential Pressure

§ Confirm DP range of the AMU

§ Isolate meter manifold so that the High (+) side is blocked-in, and the Low (-) side is vented to atmosphere

§ Using PK 400” dead weight tester, connect to the high side for testing

§ Start with PK Nitrogen Supply OFF, and VENTED – this is the ZERO

§ Then check mid-range at 200” (or 125”)

§ Then check High at 400” (or 250”)

§ All points tolerance should be with 0.2” – if any points are not within tolerance Calibrate Meter

§ Calibrate Zero, then 400”, 300”, 200”, and 100” (or 250”, 187.5”, 125”, 62.5)

§ Then repeat checks at Zero, mid-range, and high – confirm they are within tolerances

screens.name: Operations_Supply_Gas_Swapping_to_Air_Procedure
screens.label: Operations Supply Gas Swapping to Air Procedure

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Manual Draining of Fuel Gas Supply Vessel

·        Have available and use all required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, safety footwear, 4 gas monitoring device, FRC, and chemical gloves. Identify wind direction and move up wind of work area.

·        Identify fluid level in the vessel sight glass. (Hazard: If fluid level is higher than the sight glass, there is a high risk of fluid being introduced into the supply gas system and could potentially cause the safety system to fail.)

·        Check fluid level in the tank that the fluid will drain to. (Hazard: If fluid level is too high in the B/D tank while draining, it will escape thru the top access port causing a spill.)

·        SLOWLY open 1” drain ball valve to 25% Open. This valve is located at the bottom of the fuel vessel to allow fluids to drain to the tank. NEVER leave the valve unattended while vessel is being drained. (Hazard: Condensate and gas vapors pose an explosion hazard.)

·        As fluid drains out of the vessel, the fluid level will lower in the sight glass. When the fluid level falls below the bottom of the sight glass CLOSE both of the 1” drain ball valves. Fuel Gas Supply Vessels MUST be manually drained as needed. (Hazard: Draining the fluid level too low in the vessel could release a high volume of gas and over pressurize the tank.)

fields.name: Pipeline_Type
fields.fieldText: Pipeline Type

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Plunger Service:

·        Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check for wind indicator and condition prior to commencing any blowdown operations.

·        Set catch on lubricator. Hazard: Pinch Points

·        Monitor cycle time to estimated arrival on ignition. If you notice any issues (fast arrival, gas after arrival and or fluid after arrival) make the needed changes.

·        After arrival, shut crown valve. Install the proper locking device and DO NOT OPERATE tag. If more than one person is on location, each authorized employee will affix the Lock Out/Tag Out device to the group lockout device. Hazard: Pinch points

·        Shut the ball valve on the flowline Downstream of the plunger Kimray. Install the proper locking device and DO NOT OPERATE tag. If more than one person is on location, each authorized employee will affix the Lock Out/Tag Out device to the group lockout device. Hazard: Pinch Points

·        Close the needle valve under the stick pilot to trap-in the pressure. Place a LOTO tag. This will “bypass” the stick pilot. Bleed off pressure through the needle valve on plunger lubricator and hair pen downstream of plunger Kimray. Verify that the pressure has bled off by checking the gauge. Place a tag on the needle valves. Hazard: Pinch points

·        Remove lubricator cap, pull plunger with retrieval tool or magnet, and inspect (if all is good, replace plunger and release catcher). Hazards: Pinch points, H2S, Hazardous or explosive atmosphere, trapped pressure and fluids

·        Install top of lubricator, remove tag and close needle valves.

·        Remove lock and open crown valve, release catcher, and let plunger fall. Hazard: Pinch points

·        Reset the plunger page in Ignition to “fall delay” to allow the plunger to fall.

·        Remove lock and open ball valve on hair pen.

·        Monitor trip times and production on Ignition.

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Pigging

If multiple personnel are involved hold a tailgate meeting and discuss the job scope. Ensure you have all the required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, hearing protection, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check wind direction and weather conditions prior to starting the task.

Hazards:

·        Gas and fluid leak

·        Fire or explosion

·        Valves not in the correct position

·        Blocked flow

·        High pressure

·        Loud Noise

·        Flammable atmosphere

·        Trapped pressure

·        Housekeeping

·        H2S exposure

·        In the line of fire

·        Pinch Points


Receiving a pig

·        Isolate the pig receiver

·        Depressurize the pig receiver

·        Open the pig receiver

·        Carefully remove the pig

·        Close the pig receiver

·        Purge the pig receiver

·        Return all valves on receiver back to normal service

Launching a pig

·        Isolate the pig launcher

·        Depressurize the launcher

·        Open the pig launcher

·        Carefully insert a pig

·        Close the pig launcher

·        Purge the pig launcher

·        Confirm the pig has been launched

·        Return all valves on launcher back to normal service

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Gas Lift General Guidelines:

•        Vendor gas lift design sheet needs to be available for reference – this information should also be available in the Well View tubing component data table (valve open/closing pressure data).

•       Ensure all required PPE – gloves, safety glasses, hard hat, 4-gas monitor, FRC’s, and hearing protection are utilized.

•       Initial liquid displacement to the top valve should be carefully controlled as it is most susceptible to damage because the liquid column from the surface passes primarily through this valve.

•       Displacement unloading rates should not exceed 1 BPM to prevent erosion of gas lift equipment (~750 mcf/d @1200 PSI).

•       Observe wind direction prior to starting procedure.

•       Flowline choke on tubing should be fully open when unloading a gas lifted well.

 

Rocking Gas Lift Well:

•       Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check for wind indicator and condition prior to commencing any blowdown operations.

•       Shut in the well either on a computer or onsite.

•       Let casing pressure increase until all gas lift valves are open.

•       Open well to sales with injection set to current injection rate

•       If the problem is still present, then repeat the first two steps but bleed casing to sales until 200 psi lower PSC on bottom valve. Hazards: H2S, Hazardous or flammable atmosphere, trapped pressure and fluids

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Pipeline ROW Survey

If multiple personnel are involved hold a tailgate meeting and discuss the job scope. Ensure you have all the required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, hearing protection, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check wind direction and weather conditions prior to starting the task.

Hazards:

·        Gas and fluid leak

·        Loud Noise

·        Flammable or hazardous atmosphere

·        Housekeeping

·        Animals

·        H2S exposure



o  Evaluate your surroundings

o  Ensure all gates are left as they were found

o  Be aware of sinkholes

o  Be aware of high grass that could catch on fire

o  Use low speed while driving down ROW

o  Look for any wet or stained soil

o  Look for any dead grass

o  Be aware of gas, condensate or H2S odors

o  Report any corrective actions in Salesforce

o  Update line inspection record in Salesforce

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Swabbing:

•       Complete a JSA and hold Tailgate Meeting.  Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check for wind indicator and condition prior to commencing any blowdown operations.

•       Upon arrival, the vendor will lock the flowline, crown, and wing valve together while rigging up the swab unit and place a DO NOT OPERATE tag. Once rigged up the vendor may unlock. If at any time the cups need to be changed or lubricator needs to be removed from the wellhead, they must lock the crown and wing valves again. Hazard: Pinch points, H2S, Hazardous or flammable atmosphere, and pinch points

•       Once reaching the depth discussed in the JSA, the vendor will rig up and run-in hole with GR to 10,000’

•       After the GR run is complete the vendor will run-in hole with the tool string with swab tools making as many runs as needed to unload the well. Monitor casing pressures during the runs and enter swab runs in the job book. Hazards: Overhead work and Pinch points

•       After Ensign representative has returned the well to production, the vendor will rig down and move out rig and their equipment. Hazards: H2S, Hazardous or flammable atmosphere, overhead work, and pinch points

•       The Open Top Tank with all fluids will need to be emptied and the oil transferred to Blowdown Tanks at the Pod. Hazards: LEL, H2S a backing up

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Measurement task troubleshoot

·        Check density in Coriolis meter. Ensure that oil dump valve has a seat/trim that are not compromised. Flush site glass by closing gauge-cocks and dumping fluids/gas to white blowdown tank. Open site glass up to check for accurate level. If level is the problem, then adjust level controller accordingly. (Hazards: trapped pressure, fluid leak, pinch points, flammable or hazardous atmosphere)

·        Check turbine meter head for flow rate and ensure that water valve has a seat/trim that is not compromised. Flush site glass by closing gauge-cocks and dumping fluids/gas to white blowdown tank. Open site glass up to check for accurate level. If level is the problem, then adjust level controller accordingly. (Hazards: trapped pressure, fluid leak, pinch points, flammable or hazardous atmosphere)

·        If density and level are good, then put in a work order to correct issue.

·        If water meter and level are good, then pull water meter to ensure turbine is in working condition. Close upstream and downstream valves of water meter, drain fluid and trapped pressure through tubing line to white blow down tank if applicable. Check for blockage in fins, broken fins, or inoperable turbine. If blockage is removed put back in service. If turbine is inoperable put in a work order. (Hazards: pinch points, trapped pressure, manual handling, line of fire, flammable or hazardous atmosphere, fluid leak)

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Hot Water Treatment Tubing:

•       Complete a JSA and hold Tailgate Meeting. Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check for wind indicator and condition prior to commencing any blowdown operations.

•       Spot hot oil truck and transport up wind of well and/or equipment. Hazards: Flash fire, flash back from burner, ignition source, whipping hose, trapped pressure and exciding equipment pressure rating.

•       LOTO flowline and service valve.

•       Hook up Hot Oil Truck’s high-pressure hose to service valve (if no flange use choke crossover)

•       Pressure test to 1500 psi and then equalize to wellhead pressure through truck’s bypass valve. Hazards: Pressure and pinch points

•       Open Kimray and make sure safety system is locked open

•       Start pumping ¼ BPM and allow truck to reach desired temp (do not exceed 220 degrees).

•       Bring truck up to desired rate and pump designated bbl. count

•       Allow truck to cool down on the last 5 bbl. so the equipment can be removed safely. Hazards: Pressure, hot fluid, and pinch points

•       Shut of pump and close and lock service valve (open trucks bypass valve if needed)

•       Remove trucks high pressure hose and return bull plug and/or choke handle.

•       Unlock service valve and flowline valve

•       Make sure safety system is returned to original state

fields.name: Procedure_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Gas Lift General Guidelines:

•        Vendor gas lift design sheet needs to be available for reference – this information should also be in the Well View tubing component data table (valve open/closing pressure data).

•       Ensure all required PPE – gloves, safety glasses, hard hat, 4-gas monitor, FRC’s, and hearing protection are utilized.

•       Initial liquid displacement to the top valve should be carefully controlled as it is most susceptible to damage because the liquid column from the surface passes primarily through this valve.

•       Displacement unloading rates should not exceed 1 BPM to prevent erosion of gas lift equipment (~750 mcf/d @1200 PSI).

•       Observe wind direction prior to starting procedure.

•       Flowline choke on tubing should be fully open when unloading a gas lifted well.

 

Unloading Gas Lift Well:

•       Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check for wind indicator and condition prior to commencing any blowdown operations.

•       Ensure all upstream valves are open to casing, then initiate injection gas flow and control rate to attain a 50 PSI casing pressure increase in 10-minute increments.

•       Continue this injection rate until the casing pressure reaches approximately 400 PSI

•       NOTE: If the well is a packer less completion with an excess of 400 PSI initial casing pressure simply increase injection gas rate as described in step 4 from initiation of gas lift gas.

•       Increase injection gas rate to achieve a 100 PSI increase in 10-minute increments

•       NOTE: Do not exceed an injection rate greater than 50% of the designed gas lift rate during this period. The designed gas lift rate can be found on the Gas Lift Design Sheet provided by the vendor.

•       Monitor for an injection gas pressure drop and the return of aerated fluid from the production tubing to indicate that the gas is being injected into the top valve of the well.

•       Increase rate to 50% of design rate (if not already at that rate) and continue unloading process for 12-18 hours at that rate.

•       Increase rate to 75% of design rate and continue unloading process for 4-6 hours at that rate.

•       Increase rate to target design rate in 50 mcf increments allowing at least 2 hours at each rate before changing. Monitor unloading process and pressure.

•       NOTE: Do not exceed 1 BPM injection gas rate (~750 mcf/d) while unloading well.

•       Monitor casing pressure for decreases indicating well is transitioning to lower valves.

•       Document final rate of injection and point of injection to IOC and Artificial Lift Lead

fields.name: Procedure_0_0_0_0_0
fields.fieldText:
Wireline:

•       Complete a JSA and hold Tailgate Meeting Ensure that you have all your required PPE including hard hat, safety glasses, steel toed shoes, 4 gas monitoring device, and FRC. Check for wind indicator and condition prior to commencing any blowdown operations.

•       If possible, catch and remove plunger prior to slickline arrival. Hazard: Pinch points

•       MIRU slickline unit (with 0.108” slickline unless otherwise specified) and crane (or quick-rig unit).

•       Shut well in with at least 2 barriers to all pressure sources and bleed off pressure above swab/crown valve, following applicable SOPs. Hazards: H2S, Hazardous or flammable atmosphere, trapped pressure and fluids

•       RU wireline valve(s)/ram above plunger lift lubricator or on top of tree. Hazards: Overhead work, Hazardous or flammable atmosphere, H2S and pinch points

•       Pressure test lubricator to 500 psi above most recent SITP and hold for 5 minutes. Test with water when ambient temperature is >35 °F; otherwise use 50/50 water-glycol to

      avoid hydrates when well is opened. Hazard: High Pressure

•       RIH with 1.900” gauge ring to plunger (if still in hole) or BHA.

•       If tagged higher than prior setting depth of BHA, discuss with Prod. Engr. about retrieving plunger, LIB diagnostics run, smaller gauge, broach, or bailer run based on well history, depth of tag, solids sample recovered, etc. to determine path forward.

•       Document any sample material recovered in Well View in “Sample Retrieved” picklist

•       Flag line at tag depth for next run if counter gets off.

•       If plunger was not recovered in step 1, RIH with applicable pulling tool for plunger in well, latch plunger, jar free, and POOH. 2” SB if external fish-neck plunger. 1 1/2” GS if internal fish-neck plunger

•       RIH with 2” SB pulling tool to BHA, latch, jar free, and POOH. Note condition of BHA in Well View report

•       If plunger was not making normal runs or if BHA is to be run deeper in well, run dummy plunger

•       to profile/landing nipple. If BHA is to be run in same spot, run standard 1.900” gauge ring to

•       profile/landing nipple. If tag high, discuss with Prod. Engr. about broaching tubing or diagnostics run (LIB, bailer, etc.) based on well history, depth of tag, etc.

•       Make up new collar stop / bumper spring on 2” SB running tool, RIH, and locate and set in a collar within 4 joints of previous setting depth. Okay to re-run BHA if approved by AL Lead. Hazards: Overhead work and pinch points

•       If unable to set within 4 joints, discuss with AL Lead. 

•       Update plunger details as necessary if new plunger is installed with BHA and update depth of plunger if BHA is set to different depth

•       RDMO slickline unit and associated equipment; return well to production.
